name: TheAtlantic
text: "I’ve always said that a day at camp is like two weeks in real life. Every emotion, friendship, and romantic feeling is amplified. On those campgrounds, an extraordinary, emotional magic takes place," @thedih13 writes: https://t.co/CQcqWytFNl

name: TheAtlantic
text: Black faces have long been considered a threat by American law enforcement. Facial-recognition technology poses a major threat to Black people, @culturejedi writes. https://t.co/CYea8JcHug

name: TheAtlantic
text: "When will the protests end? And what will it mean when they do? Although all waves of mass protest are different, they tend to follow a similar course," @markjengler writes: https://t.co/VwhhT2nTDi

name: TheAtlantic
text: “The way many think of custodial staff does not reflect the value that they provide to hospitals," @RepMarkTakano told @jasper_craven recently. “They are critical to infection control; we need to see these employees as skilled workers.” https://t.co/sMoxlZPEMN

name: TheAtlantic
text: "My heart and blood recede / but my electrics seem to be in love / ceaselessly conversing. / I don’t agree to this hallucination. / I like the decadent / privacy of text / but a part of it feels mistaken." https://t.co/4f7Vx9nKiq

name: TheAtlantic
text: “The way many think of custodial staff does not reflect the value that they provide to hospitals," @RepMarkTakano told @jasper_craven recently. “They are critical to infection control; we need to see these employees as skilled workers.” https://t.co/OX89kk7xsF

name: TheAtlantic
text: Police have long used dogs to sniff out human remains. Now, @jillneimark reports, archaeologists are using them to uncover bones buried thousands of years ago. https://t.co/wwJnuPKVUV

name: TheAtlantic
text: "[W. E. B.] Du Bois’s 1920 book, 'Darkwater: Voices From Within the Veil,' offers us a clarion call to action, to imagine a better tomorrow and continue, even in the face of death, to live, to fight, and to love," @Dr_ChadWilliams writes: https://t.co/6Cp3H0e3LR

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Individuals are being asked to decide for themselves what chances they should take," @tesswilkry writes, "but a century of research on human cognition shows that people are bad at assessing risk in complex situations." https://t.co/3LOfcNYr7t

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @JeffreyGoldberg: "Four months of stay-at-home orders have proved that, if schools are unavailable, a city cannot work, a community cannot function, a nation cannot safeguard itself." -- @juliettekayyem:
https://t.co/pj5leMEbmF

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @conor64: I lived on Rose Avenue in Venice Beach for 7 years. I saw a lot of crime. And I witnessed the LAPD shoot and kill someone.

Here's what I think about the best way forward there after years of observation.

https://t.co/DNtdCp2wB9

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @danteramos: “Americans’ disgust should be aimed at governments and institutions, not at one another… If a business is open but you would be foolish to visit it, that is a failure of leadership.” Read @tesswilkry on the psychological morass of reopening: https://t.co/gyOf2oaaoV

name: TheAtlantic
text: In this week’s Dear Therapist, @LoriGottlieb1 advises a reader whose daughter came out as trans. https://t.co/TPb0nfPFXl

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @beccarosen: This is a beautiful piece of writing by @dereckapurnell https://t.co/v101IJsxAr

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The problem isn’t that policy makers—many of them parents too—don’t know what families are going through," @juliettekayyem writes. "It’s that, fundamentally, the way public officials thought about the consequences of this crisis was flawed." https://t.co/msbPYhDnFc

name: TheAtlantic
text: Embracing marijuana legalization could be an easy win for Joe Biden. But he remains reluctant, @IsaacDovere reports. https://t.co/QDXXn7ED9o

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Rather than thinking of abolition as just getting rid of police, I think about it as an invitation to create and support lots of different answers to the problem of harm in society," @dereckapurnell writes: https://t.co/78SQWJg10C

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @PeterAtlantic: There exists a quiet network of Black pastors and staffers who serve as unofficial racism consultants to the white evangelical world, @emmaogreen reports: https://t.co/8EhTj3SR7g

name: TheAtlantic
text:
A Russian court has convicted the freelance journalist Svetlana Prokopyeva for “justifying terrorism.”

“The investigation of Prokopyeva is symptomatic of the worsening environment for free expression in Russia,” @annanemtsova wrote last year. https://t.co/XJ1gVKTG13

name: TheAtlantic
text: "In recent weeks, the protests over the killing of George Floyd have provoked an unusually wide-ranging debate about how to respond to police violence. Earmark funds for reform? Defund the police? Abolish them?" @conor64 writes: https://t.co/2T1JekXT4n

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @thebanderson: “Reports from multiple states, including those presently experiencing large coronavirus outbreaks, paint a bleak picture of nursing-home readiness for a COVID-19 surge.”

The tragedy is that it will have been preventable. 

Read @olgakhazan's latest: https://t.co/u6uWudL8HP

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "The notion that schools can’t open again to students until a vaccine arrives should not be the guiding moral standard. The vaccine may never come..." https://t.co/d6TZhUqFcz

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @olgakhazan: There's this impression that nursing-home residents had to die because elderly. But I profile two examples—one international and one domestic—that had *no* nursing-home COVID deaths. We could have done this at a national scale. We didn't.  https://t.co/f1Z9FZ4YcA

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @rachgutman: "'Police abolition' initially repulsed me. The idea seemed white and utopic. I’d seen too much sexual violence and buried too many friends to consider getting rid of police in St. Louis, let alone the nation. But in reality, the police were a placebo." https://t.co/L1CpqdD3za

name: TheAtlantic
text: “I think we really dropped the ball here." @olgakhazan reports on why the U.S. allowed so many elderly people to die, and why there might still be more COVID-19 deaths in nursing homes to come: https://t.co/NaAnMmhIyq

name: TheAtlantic
text: Alternate histories often double as warnings. But these days, @megangarber writes, they’re doing something else, as well: providing a space to grieve the futures that might have been. https://t.co/jbCDQE02uY

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @LoriGottlieb1: “Your daughter’s revelation came at another transition: your child becoming an adult. You’re losing what every parent does—your role in your child’s life as she becomes her true self separate from you.”

This week @theatlantic: How to love & let go

https://t.co/99ttGgEG6E

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @yayitsrob: Read @olgakhazan on how America’s nursing homes—including those in the Sun Belt—are still unprepared for the pandemic: https://t.co/YwIxQ6zrgO
